ao_nodesao.c

Go to the documentation of this file.
00001 /*****************************************************************************
00002 
00003   Description: This file contains C routines that navigate among the object
00004                nodes of an ODL tree.  These routines augment the general
00005                purpose routines for manipulating aggregate nodes.  The main
00006                differences between these routines and the general routines
00007                for handling aggregates are the following:
00008 
00009                  - These routines ignore group nodes when navigating through
00010                    an ODL tree;
00011 
00012                  - The search routines FindObject and FindNextObject are
00013                    able to search for a specific class of object as well
00014                    as for an object node with a specific name.
00015  
00016   Author:  Randy Davis, University of Colorado LASP
00017  
00018   Creation Date:  13 March 1991
00019   Last Modified:  18 May 1991
00020 
00021   History:
00022 
00023     Creation - This set of routines was introduced in the Version 2.1
00024     release of the ODLC library.
00025 
00026   Version 2.2 - 18 May 1991 - M. DeMore, Jet Propulsion Laboratory
00027     Removed include statements that were Unix specific and placed them
00028     in odldef.h.
00029 
00030 *****************************************************************************/
00031 
00032 #include  "odldef.h"
00033 #include  "odlinter.h"
00034 
00035 
00036 
00037 
00038 
00039 /*****************************************************************************
00040 
00041   Routine: ParentObject
00042  
00043   Description: Returns a pointer to an aggregate's parent object.  
00044  
00045   Input:
00046           base_node - A pointer to an aggregate node.
00047  
00048   Output: A pointer to the parent object node.  If there is no parent object
00049           (if, for example, the input base node is the root node of an ODL
00050           tree) then the NULL value is returned.  The NULL value is also
00051           returned if the input argument is NULL.
00052 
00053 *****************************************************************************/
00054  
00055 
00056 OBJECT ParentObject (AGGREGATE base_node)
00057 {
00058   AGGREGATE  node;               /* Pointer to current aggregate node       */
00059 
00060 
00061   node = base_node;
00062 
00063   do
00064     {
00065       node = ParentAggregate (node);
00066     } while (node != NULL && node->kind != KA_OBJECT);
00067 
00068   return (node);
00069 }
00070 
00071 
00072 
00073 
00074 /*****************************************************************************
00075 
00076   Routine: NextObject
00077  
00078   Description: Returns the next object node after the one pointed to by the
00079                input aggregate node, according to a pre-order traversal of
00080                the ODL tree.
00081  
00082   Input:
00083           base_node  - A pointer to the starting aggregate node.
00084  
00085   Output: A pointer to the next object node is returned as the function
00086           value.  A NULL value indicates that there is no next object
00087           node.  The NULL value is also returned if the input argument
00088           is NULL.
00089 
00090 *****************************************************************************/
00091  
00092 
00093 OBJECT NextObject (AGGREGATE base_node)
00094 {
00095   AGGREGATE  node;                    /* Pointer to the next node           */
00096 
00097 
00098   node = base_node;
00099 
00100   do
00101     {
00102       node = NextAggregate (node);
00103     } while (node != NULL && node->kind != KA_OBJECT);
00104 
00105   return node;
00106 }
00107 
00108 
00109 
00110 
00111 /*****************************************************************************
00112 
00113   Routine: NextSubObject
00114  
00115   Description: Returns the next sub-object of the base node after the one
00116                pointed to by the start node.
00117  
00118   Input:
00119           base_node  - A pointer to the base aggregate node.
00120           start_node - A pointer to the starting node.
00121  
00122   Output: A pointer to the next object sub-node of the base node is
00123           returned as the function value.  A NULL value indicates that
00124           there is no next object sub-node.  The NULL value is also
00125           returned if the input argument is NULL.
00126 
00127 *****************************************************************************/
00128  
00129 
00130 OBJECT NextSubObject (AGGREGATE base_node, AGGREGATE start_node)
00131 {
00132   AGGREGATE  node;                    /* Pointer to the next node           */
00133 
00134 
00135   node = start_node;
00136 
00137   do
00138     {
00139       node = NextSubAggregate (base_node, node);
00140     } while (node != NULL && node->kind != KA_OBJECT);
00141 
00142   return node;
00143 }
00144 
00145 
00146 
00147 
00148 /*****************************************************************************
00149 
00150   Routine: FindObject
00151  
00152   Description: Finds an object node with a specified name and/or class.
00153                The search starts with the base node and continues as
00154                necessary with all of the base nodes's children, all their
00155                children, and so on using a preorder search.
00156  
00157   Input:
00158           base_node - A pointer to the starting aggregate node.
00159           name      - Pointer to a character string containing the object
00160                       name to be located. This may be NULL; if it is, the
00161                       search will be for the first object node of the
00162                       specified class.
00163           thisClass  - Pointer to a character string with the object class
00164                       to be located. This may be NULL; if it is, the search
00165                       will be for the first object node with the specified
00166                       name, regardless of its class.
00167  
00168   Output: A pointer to the first object node that has the specified name
00169           and/or class is returned as the function value. If no match is
00170           found, then the NULL value is returned.  The NULL value is also
00171           returned if the input pointer to the base node is NULL or if
00172           both the input name and class are NULL.
00173 
00174 *****************************************************************************/
00175  
00176 
00177 OBJECT FindObject (AGGREGATE base_node, char *name, char *thisClass)
00178 {
00179   AGGREGATE  node;                    /* Pointer to current node           */
00180 
00181 
00182   if (base_node == NULL || (name == NULL && thisClass == NULL))
00183     { 
00184       return (NULL);
00185     }
00186 
00187   /* Start searching with the base node and stop searching when we
00188      find a node with the specified name and/or class or when we
00189      have visited all of the progeny of the base node  */
00190 
00191   node = base_node;
00192 
00193   while (node != NULL)
00194     {
00195       if (node->kind == KA_OBJECT &&
00196           (name  == NULL || strcmp (node->name,  name)  == 0) &&
00197           (thisClass == NULL || strcmp (node->objClass, thisClass) == 0))
00198         {
00199           break;
00200         }
00201 
00202       node = NextSubObject (base_node, node);
00203     }
00204 
00205   return (node);
00206 }
00207 
00208 
00209 
00210 /*****************************************************************************
00211 
00212   Routine: FindNextObject
00213  
00214   Description: This routine is similar to routine FindObject in that it
00215                searches the progeny of the specified base node, except that
00216                the search begins with the node specified by the second
00217                argument. This is useful when there is more than one object
00218                node with the same name or class in the search path.
00219 
00220   Input:
00221           base_node  - A pointer to the base node for the search.
00222           start_node - A pointer to the starting node for the search.  The
00223                        search does not include the start node.
00224           name       - Pointer to a character string containing the name of
00225                        the object to be located.  This pointer can be NULL:
00226                        if it is, the first object node of the specified
00227                        class is returned, regardless of its name.
00228           class      - Pointer to a character string containing the class of
00229                        object to be located. If this pointer is NULL, the
00230                        first object node located with the specified name
00231                        is returned, regardless of its class.
00232  
00233   Output: A pointer to the next object node that has the specified name
00234           and/or class is returned as function value. If no match is
00235           found, then the NULL value is returned.  The NULL value is
00236           also returned if either the input base node or start node
00237           pointers are NULL, or if both the name and class arguments
00238           are NULL.
00239 
00240 *****************************************************************************/
00241  
00242 
00243 OBJECT FindNextObject (AGGREGATE base_node, AGGREGATE start_node, char *name, char *thisClass)
00244 {
00245   AGGREGATE  node;                    /* Pointer to current node           */
00246 
00247 
00248   if (base_node == NULL || start_node == NULL ||
00249       (name == NULL && thisClass == NULL))
00250     {
00251       return (NULL);
00252     }
00253 
00254   /* Start searching from the start node and stop searching when we
00255      find an object node with the specified name and/or class, or
00256      when we have visited all of the progeny of the base node  */
00257 
00258   node = NextSubObject (base_node, start_node);
00259 
00260   while (node != NULL)
00261     { 
00262       if ((name  == NULL || strcmp (node->name,  name)  == 0) &&
00263           (thisClass == NULL || strcmp (node->objClass, thisClass) == 0))
00264         {
00265           break;
00266         }
00267 
00268       node = NextSubObject (base_node, node);
00269     }
00270 
00271   return (node);
00272 }
